revision.text:
{{Infobox earthquake |title = 1693 Sicily earthquake |pre-1900 = yes |image = Sicilia Sisma 1693.jpg |image alt = |imagecaption = [[Isoseismal map]] for the 1693 earthquake |map = |map alt = |image name = |map2 = {{Location map | Italy Sicily | relief=yes | label= | lat=37.3 | long=15.1 | mark=Bullseye1.png | marksize=70 | position=top | width= 260 | float=center | caption=}} |mapsize = |caption = |local-date = {{Start-date|January 11, 1693}} |local-time = 21:00[https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/world/historical_country.php#italy USGS: "1693 01 11 – Sicily, Italy – M 7.5 Fatalities 60,000"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728221758/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/world/historical_country.php |date=2010-07-28 }} |duration = |magnitude = 7.4 [[Moment magnitude scale|Mw]] |depth = |location = {{coord|37.3|15.1|display=inline, title}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=1129&t=101650&s=13&d=22,26,13,12&nd=display|title=Significant Earthquake|author=National Geophysical Data Center|author-link=National Geophysical Data Center|accessdate=11 January 2012}}
The exact location of the epicentre remains uncertain |type = |countries affected = Southern [[Italy]], notably [[Sicily]], and [[Malta]][http://www.earth-prints.org/bitstream/2122/4360/1/03galea.pdf Seismic history of the Maltese islands and considerations on seismic risk], Pauline Galea – Physics Department, University of Malta, Msida, Malta, ANNALS OF GEOPHYSICS, VOL. 50, N. 6, December 2007 |damage = |intensity = [[Mercalli intensity scale|XI (''Extreme'')]] |PGA = |tsunami = 5–10 meter high waves devastated the coastal villages on the Ionian Sea and in the Straits of Messina. (Ambraseys-Sieberg intensity V tsunami) |landslide = |foreshocks = A magnitude 6.2 on January 9 |aftershocks = |casualties = 60,000 deaths{{cite journal|first1=Fernando|last1=Rodríguez de la Torre|year=1995|title=Spanish sources concerning the 1693 earthquake in Sicily|journal=Annali di Geofisica|pages=526|volume=38|issue=5–6|url=http://www.earth-prints.org/bitstream/2122/1744/1/06%20torre.pdf}}, [[Juan Francisco Pacheco y Téllez-Girón, 4th Consort Duke of Uceda]] the Spanish [[Viceroy of Sicily]] at the time reports ''((...) and about sixty thousand people died under the ruins of the earthquake)''(August 4, 1695) }} The '''1693 Sicily earthquake''' struck parts of southern [[Italy]] near [[Sicily]], [[Calabria]], and [[Malta]] on [[January 11]] at around 21:00 local time. This earthquake was preceded by a damaging [[foreshock]] on January 9.Gutscher, M.-A., J. Roger, M.-A. Baptista, J. M. Miranda, and S. Tinti (2006), [http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/11/11/63/PDF/GRL-Gutscher-06.pdf Source of the 1693 Catania earthquake and tsunami (southern Italy): New evidence from tsunami modeling of a locked subduction fault plane], Geophys. Res. Lett., 33, L08309, {{doi|10.1029/2005GL025442}}. The main quake had an estimated magnitude of 7.4 on the [[moment magnitude scale]], the most powerful in Italian history, and a maximum intensity of XI (''Extreme'') on the [[Mercalli intensity scale]], destroying at least 70 towns and cities, seriously affecting an area of {{convert|5600|km2|sqmi}} and causing the death of about 60,000 people. The earthquake was followed by tsunamis that devastated the coastal villages on the [[Ionian Sea]] and in the [[Straits of Messina]].[ftp://ftp.ingv.it/pub/alessio.piatanesi/PAPERS/1998_JGR_sicily.pdf A revision of the 1693 eastern Sicily earthquake and tsunami], Authors:Piatanesi, Alessio; Tinti, Stefano, Publication:Journal of Geophysical Research, Volume 103, Issue B2, p. 2749-2758 (JGR Homepage),Publication Date:02/1998, {{doi|10.1029/97JB03403}} ([ftp://ftp.ingv.it/pub/alessio.piatanesi/PAPERS/1998_JGR_sicily.pdf Full report]) Almost two thirds of the entire population of [[Catania]] were killed. The [[Epicenter|epicentre]] of the disaster was probably close to the coast, possibly offshore, although the exact position remains unknown. The extent and degree of destruction caused by the earthquake resulted in extensive rebuilding of the towns and cities of southeastern Sicily, particularly the [[Val di Noto]], in a homogeneous late [[Baroque]] style, described as "the culmination and final flowering of Baroque art in Europe".{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1024|title=Late Baroque Towns of the Val di Noto (South-Eastern Sicily)|author=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|author-link=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|work=World Heritage List|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=22 November 2011}} According to a contemporary account of the earthquake by Vincentius Bonajutus, published in the ''[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]]'', "It was in this country impossible to keep upon our legs, or in one place on the dancing Earth; nay, those that lay along on the ground, were tossed from side to side, as if on a rolling billow."Bonajutus, V. and M. Malpighius. "[https://archive.org/details/philtrans06207627 An Account of the Earthquakes in Sicilia, on the Ninth and Eleventh of January, 1692/3]" ''Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society''. January 1, 1694 18:2–10. ==Tectonic setting== Sicily lies on part of the complex [[convergent boundary]] where the [[African Plate]] is [[subduction|subducting]] beneath the [[Eurasian Plate]]. This subduction zone is responsible for the formation of the [[stratovolcano]] [[Mount Etna]] and considerable seismic activity. Most damaging earthquakes however, occur on the Siculo-Calabrian rift zone. This zone of extensional faulting runs for about {{convert|370|km|mi}}, forming three main segments through Calabria, along the east coast of Sicily and immediately offshore, and finally forming the southeastern margin of the [[Hyblaean Mountains|Hyblaean Plateau]]. Faults in the Calabrian segment were responsible for the [[1783 Calabrian earthquakes]] sequence.{{cite journal|last=Catalano|first=S.|author2=De Guidi G.|author3=Monaco C.|author4=Tortorici G.|author5=Tortorici L.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2008|title=Active faulting and seismicity along the Siculo–Calabrian Rift Zone (Southern Italy)|journal=Tectonophysics|publisher=Elsevier|volume=453|issue=1–4|pages=177–192|doi=10.1016/j.tecto.2007.05.008|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040195108000553|accessdate=19 November 2011|bibcode = 2008Tectp.453..177C }} In the southern part of the eastern coast of Sicily, investigations have identified a series of active [[Fault (geology)#Dip-slip faults|normal faults]], dipping to the east. Most of these lie offshore and some control basins that contain large thicknesses of [[Quaternary]] sediments. The two largest faults, known as the western and eastern master faults, border [[half-graben]]s with fills of up to {{convert|700|m|ft}} and {{convert|800|m|ft}} respectively. Onshore, two ages of faulting have been recognised, an earlier phase trending NW-SE and a later phase trending SSW-NNE that clearly offsets the first group, including the Avola fault and the Rosolini-Ispica fault system.{{cite journal|last=Bianca|first=M.|author2=Monaco C.|author3=Tortorici L.|author4=Cernobori L.|last-author-amp=yes|year=1999|title=Quaternary normal faulting in southeastern Sicily (Italy): a seismic source for the 1693 large earthquake|journal=[[Geophysical Journal International]]|publisher=[[Royal Astronomical Society]]|location=London|volume=139|issue=2|pages=370–394|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?db_key=AST&bibcode=1999GeoJI.139..370B&letter=0&classic=YES&defaultprint=YES&whole_paper=YES&page=370&epage=370&send=Send+PDF&filetype=.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2011|bibcode = 1999GeoJI.139..370B |doi = 10.1046/j.1365-246X.1999.00942.x }} ==Earthquake characteristics== [[File:Siculo-Calabrian Rift.png|thumb|Main faults of the Siculo-Calabrian rift zone]] ===January 9 foreshock=== A destructive earthquake occurred two days before the mainshock at 21:00 local time, centered in the Val di Noto. It had an estimated magnitude of 6.2 and a maximum perceived intensity of VIII–XI on the [[Mercalli intensity scale]]. Intensities of VIII or higher have been estimated for [[Augusta, Sicily|Augusta]], [[Avola|Avola Vecchia]], [[Floridia]], [[Melilli]], [[Noto|Noto Antica]], [[Catania]], [[Francofonte]], [[Lentini]], [[Scicli]], [[Sortino]] and [[Vizzini]].{{Cite web|url=http://storing.ingv.it/cfti4med/quakes/01148.html|title= Catalogue of Strong Earthquakes in Italy (461 BC – 1997) and Mediterranean Area (760 B.C. – 1500)|last=Guidoboni|first=E.|author2=Ferrari G.|author3=Mariotti D.|author4=Comastri A.|author5=Tarabusi G.|author6=Valensise G.|last-author-amp=yes|publisher=INGV-SGA|accessdate=20 November 2011}} Augusta lies well outside the main zone of severe shaking; its extensive damage is probably due to its construction on unconsolidated sediments. From the shape and location of the area of maximum damage, this earthquake is thought to have been caused by movement on the Avola fault. ===January 11 mainshock=== The earthquake lasted for four minutes, according to contemporary accounts. The estimated magnitude of 7.4 is taken from the extent and degree of the recorded damage, with a very large area that reached X (''Extreme'') or more on the Mercalli scale. The maximum shaking reached XI in the towns of [[Buscemi]], [[Floridia]], [[Melilli]], [[Grammichele|Occhiola]] and [[Sortino]]. The source of the January 11 earthquake is debated. Some catalogues give an onshore epicentre without any direct association with a known structure, while others propose that the source was offshore due to the associated tsunami, involving either rupture along a normal fault, part of the Siculo-Calabrian rift zone, or rupture along the subduction zone beneath the Ionian Sea. An analysis of the distribution of tsunami run-ups along the coast suggests that a submarine landslide triggered by the earthquake is the most likely source, in which case the tsunami provides no constraint on the epicenter.{{cite journal|last=Billi|first=A.|author2=Minelli L.|author3=Orecchio B.|author4=Presti D.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2010|title=Constraints to the Cause of Three Historical Tsunamis (1908, 1783, and 1693) in the Messina Straits Region, Sicily, Southern Italy|journal=Seismological Research Letters|publisher=Seismological Society of America|volume=81|issue=6|pages=907–915|doi=10.1785/gssrl.81.6.907|url=http://171.66.125.217/content/81/6/907.full.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225233247/http://171.66.125.217/content/81/6/907.full.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=25 February 2012|accessdate=20 November 2011}} A landslide origin is supported by the observation of possible landslide bodies along the Hyblean-Malta escarpment.{{cite journal|title=New contributions to the debate on the cause of the January 11th, 1693 tsunami in eastern Sicily (Italy): earthquake or offshore landslide source (or may be both)?|volume=53|last=Armigliato|first=A.|author2=Tinti S.|author3=Zaniboni F.|author4=Pagnoni G.|author5=Argnani A.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2007|work=American Geophysical Union, Fall Meeting 2007, abstract #S53A-1019|accessdate=|bibcode=2007AGUFM.S53A1019A}} Historic documents in the [[Archivo General de Simancas]] mention dozens of aftershocks, some as late as August 1694, and some reportedly as strong as the initial quake of January 11, 1693.{{cite journal|first1=Fernando|last1=Rodríguez de la Torre|year=1995|title=Spanish sources concerning the 1693 earthquake in Sicily|journal=Annali di Geofisica|pages=531|volume=38|issue=5–6|url=http://www.earth-prints.org/bitstream/2122/1744/1/06%20torre.pdf}}, '''Table I.''' List of aftershocks 1693–1694 from the AGS documents. Aftershocks continued until at least 1696, with their effects concentrated in towns along the coast, supporting an epicenter either near the coast or offshore. ==Tsunami== The tsunami triggered by the earthquake affected most of the Ionian Sea coast of Sicily, about {{convert|230|km|mi}} in all. The first thing that was noted at all localities affected was a withdrawal of the sea. The strongest effects were concentrated around Augusta, where the initial withdrawal left the harbour dry, followed by a wave of at least {{convert|2.4|m|ft}} height, possibly as much as {{convert|8|m|ft}}, that inundated part of the town. The maximum inundation of about {{convert|1.5|km|mi}} was recorded at [[Mascali]].{{cite journal|last=Gerardi|first=P.|author2=Barbano M.S.|author3=De Martini P.M.|author4=Pantosti D.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2008|title=Discrimination of Tsunami Sources (Earthquake versus Landslide) on the Basis of Historical Data in Eastern Sicily and Southern Calabria|journal=Bulletin of the Seismological Society of America|volume=98|issue=6|pages=2795–2805|doi=10.1785/0120070192|url=http://www.earth-prints.org/bitstream/2122/4119/2/Gerardi%20manuscript%202007192.pdf|accessdate=20 November 2011|bibcode = 2008BuSSA..98.2795G }} [[Tsunami deposit]]s linked to the 1693 tsunami have been found both onshore and offshore. At Ognina, just south of Syracuse, at the head of a [[ria]], a sequence containing several coarse clastic layers has been found, inconsistent with its lagoonal setting. The uppermost coarse layer, which has a strongly erosive base, consists of coarse sand with up to granule size clasts. The layer has been dated as 17th to 18th century based on pottery shards and one well-preserved clay pipe, consistent with the 1693 tsunami.{{cite journal|last=Scicchitano|first=G.|author2=Costa B.|author3=Di Stefano A.|author4=Longhitano S.|author5=Monaco C.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2008|title=Tsunami deposits in the Siracusa coastal area (south-eastern Sicily)|journal=Rend. online SGI Note Brevi|publisher=Società Geologica Italiana|volume=1|pages=159–162|url=http://www.socgeol.info/Ricerca/documents/rendiconti_online_1_2008_140_221.pdf#page=20|accessdate=21 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225233258/http://www.socgeol.info/Ricerca/documents/rendiconti_online_1_2008_140_221.pdf#page=20|archive-date=2012-02-25|dead-url=yes|df=}} Offshore from Augusta, a sequence identified using [[chirp]] [[sonar]] data was sampled with a {{convert|6.7|m|ft}} [[Core sample|gravity core]] in {{convert|72|m|ft}} of water. Following detailed analysis of both grain size and [[foraminifera]] assemblages, eleven possible high-energy events were found based on the presence of large numbers of shallow water forams combined with a greater proportion of fine sand in the same interval. The uppermost two events correlate well with the tsunamis from the [[1908 Messina earthquake]] and the 1693 earthquake.{{cite journal|last=Smedile|first=A.|author2=De Martini P.M.|author3=Pantosti D.|author4=Bellucci L.|author5=Del Carlo P.|author6=Gasperini L.|author7=Pirrotta C.|author8=Polonia A.|author9=Boschi E.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2011|title=Possible tsunami signatures from an integrated study in the Augusta Bay offshore (Eastern Sicily—Italy)|journal=Marine Geology|publisher=Elsevier|volume=281|issue=1–4|pages=1–13|doi=10.1016/j.margeo.2011.01.002|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025322711000041|accessdate=21 November 2011|bibcode=2011MGeol.281....1S}} ==Link to eruption of Etna== Although there are reports of an eruption at the time of the earthquake, most sources suggest that the volcano had been inactive since the destructive [[Mount Etna#Historical eruptions|eruption of 1669]]. Analysis of the relationship between eruptions and earthquakes has found that earthquakes are followed by long periods without activity in the 'rift zones' that extend out to north and south from the summit. Estimates of [[Coulomb stress transfer]] due to the [[Dike (geology)|dyke]] intrusion in the rift zones associated with the 1669 eruption, suggest that this could have helped to trigger the 1693 earthquake, by increasing stress levels on the faults.{{cite journal|last=Feuillet|first=N.|author2=Cocco M.|author3=Musumeci C.|author4=Nostro C.|last-author-amp=yes|year=2006|title=Stress interaction between seismic and volcanic activity at Mt Etna|journal=Geophysical Journal International|publisher=[[Royal Astronomical Society]]|location=London|volume=164|issue=3|pages=697–718|doi=10.1111/j.1365-246X.2005.02824.x|url=http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?db_key=AST&bibcode=2006GeoJI.164..697F&letter=0&classic=YES&defaultprint=YES&whole_paper=YES&page=697&epage=697&send=Send+PDF&filetype=.pdf|accessdate=20 November 2011|bibcode = 2006GeoJI.164..697F }} ==Damage== [[File:1693 Sicily earthquake.jpg|thumb|Depiction of the earthquake in an engraving from 1696, possibly showing [[Catania]]]] [[File:Castello di Noto.JPG|thumb|Ruins of the Norman castle in Noto Antica]] ===January 9 foreshock=== Despite the difficulty of separating the effects of this event from the mainshock, some information is available. This earthquake caused widespread damage, particularly in Augusta where almost half of the houses were destroyed. Most of the buildings in two districts of Avola collapsed and many buildings were also destroyed in Noto, Floridia, Lentini and Mellili. Some buildings collapsed in Catania, Vizzini and Sortini. There were an estimated 200 deaths in both Augusta and Noto. ===January 11 mainshock=== The area of severe damage covered most of southeastern Sicily, an area of about {{convert|14000|km2|sqmi}}, including all the present provinces of [[Province of Catania|Catania]], [[Province of Ragusa|Ragusa]] and [[Province of Syracuse|Syracuse]]. At least 70 cities, towns and villages were devastated, with some examples of at least partial building collapse as far afield as [[Messina]], [[Agrigento]], [[Palermo]], [[Reggio Calabria]] and [[Malta]]. The earthquake also triggered large landslides, such as at Noto Antica and Sortino, and in one case a large rock-slide dammed a stream, forming a lake a few kilometres long. Several large NW-SE trending fractures were created up to {{convert|500|m|ft}} long and {{convert|2|m|ft}} wide, on the plains just south of Catania. In the same area, [[sand volcano]]es were formed by jets of water spurting as much as several metres into the air, with similar phenomena being reported from the Lentini plain and along some river valleys. At Augusta the tsunami damaged galleys of the [[Knights of Malta]] that were anchored in the harbour when they were grounded during the initial withdrawal of the sea. The number of deaths recorded at the time in official sources were about 12,000 in Catania (63% of the population), 5,045 in Ragusa (51%), 3,500 in Syracuse (23%) 3,000 in Noto (25%), 1,840 in Augusta (30%) and 3,400 in [[Modica]] (19%). The total death toll in the same source was recorded as 54,000 with other sources referring to totals of about 60,000. In 1853, [[Robert Mallet|Mallet]] recorded 93,000 deaths, in his catalogue of earthquakes. ==Aftermath== [[File:La cattedrale di Noto restaurata.JPG|thumb|The Cathedral of Noto, one of the many buildings constructed in [[Sicilian Baroque]] style after the earthquake]] ===Response=== Sicily was at the time ruled as part of the [[Crown of Aragon]] by the [[List of Spanish monarchs|Kings of Spain]]. The [[List of viceroys of Sicily|Viceroy]] in Madrid, the [[Juan Francisco Pacheco y Téllez-Girón, 4th Consort Duke of Uceda|Duke of Uzeda]], reacted by appointing [[Giuseppe Lanza]], the Duke of Camastra, and the Prince of Aragon as [[Vicar general|Vicars General]] for the Val Demone and Val di Noto regions of Sicily respectively. Due to illness, both the Prince of Aragon and his replacement the bishop of Syracuse were unable to take up the position of Vicar General for Val di Noto and the Duke of Camastra was forced to take on the responsibility for both areas. Camastra already had considerable experience as an administrator, having served in a number of senior military and judicial positions. The Viceroy also appointed three generals as commissioners in order to organise the immediate relief efforts in the worst affected cities. One of the Duke of Camastra's first acts was to temporarily exempt the worst affected areas from taxes. Amongst other administrators sent to the damaged area was Colonel Don [[Carlos de Grunenbergh]], Royal Engineer to the King of Spain, who had experience in planning and building fortifications. In Palermo, the Viceroy formed two councils, a civil one made up of nobles, and another that was ecclesiastical, made up of senior church officials. They were directed to meet twice weekly,{{cite book|last=Tobriner|first=S.|title=The Genesis of Noto: An Eighteenth-century Sicilian City|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gR7IxxQiX5UC&pg=PA13|series=Studies in Architecture|volume=21|year=1982|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-03526-3|pages=27–37}} and were charged with the drawing up of plans for the reconstruction of the worst affected towns and cities. ===Reconstruction=== {{see| Vincenzo Sinatra}} [[File:Malta - Mdina - Pjazza San Pawl + St. Paul's Cathedral ex 01 ies.jpg|thumb|The [[Maltese Baroque architecture|Maltese Baroque]] [[St. Paul's Cathedral, Mdina|Cathedral of Mdina]], built in 1696–1705 after the original cathedral was damaged in the earthquake]] The initial reconstruction efforts concentrated on restoring the military defences of Syracuse, Augusta, Catania and Acireale, due to their strategic importance. The reconstruction plans were of three types: move the town to a new site, rebuild at the same site with a completely new town plan or rebuild using the existing town plan. Examples of towns that fell in the first category were Avola and Noto, their former locations now being known as Avola Antica{{cite web|url=http://www.siracusa-sicilia.it/english/avola.htm|title=Avola|last=Siracusa-sicilia|accessdate=20 November 2011}} and Noto Antica.{{cite web|url=http://www.siracusa-sicilia.it/english/noto_antica.htm|title=Noto Antica|last=Siracusa-sicilia|accessdate=20 November 2011}} Catania is an example of a city that was rebuilt on the same site to a new plan, while adapting some of the existing structures. Syracuse is an example of a city rebuilt entirely to its existing plan. Ragusa was partly rebuilt on its old site to the medieval plan (''Ragusa Ibla'') and partly on a new, but neighbouring site, to a 'modern' plan (''Ragusa Superiore''). The degree and extent of the damage caused by the earthquake prompted an architectural revival in the towns of [[Sicily]] and [[Malta]], a style that has become known as [[Sicilian Baroque]].{{cite book|last=Valdes|first=G.|title=Art and History: Sicily|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CpUEb1atzNQC&pg=PA9|accessdate=22 November 2011|year=2003|publisher=Casa Editrice Bonechi|isbn=978-88-476-0756-9|page=9}} At this time many of the palazzi, public buildings, cathedrals and churches were reconstructed in this style. Towns that suffered serious damage from the earthquake in which many of their structures were rebuilt, include [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]], [[Ragusa, Italy|Ragusa]], [[Catania]],{{cite web|last=Condorelli|first=Stefano|title=The Reconstruction of Catania after the Earthquake of 1693|url=https://www.academia.edu/2640421/The_Reconstruction_of_Catania_after_the_Earthquake_of_1693|work=Proceedings of the Second International Congress on Construction History (Queens’ College Cambridge 2006), Exeter, Short Run Press, 2006, I, pp. 799–815}} [[Caltagirone]], [[Palazzolo Acreide]], [[Modica]], [[Comiso]], [[Scicli]] and [[Mdina]] on [[Malta]]. Many of these towns now form part of the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] ''Late Baroque Towns of the Val di Noto (South-Eastern Sicily)'', inscribed in 1992, referring to the "exceptional quality" of the region's art and architecture. ==See also== *[[List of earthquakes in Italy]] *[[List of historical earthquakes]] *[[Sicilian Baroque#Sicilian Baroque from 1693|Sicilian Baroque from 1693]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Earthquakes in Italy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1693 Sicily Earthquake}} [[Category:Earthquakes in Italy]] [[Category:1693 in Italy|Sicily]] [[Category:1693 earthquakes|Sicily]] [[Category:Geography of Malta]] [[Category:Disasters in Sicily]] [[Category:Sicilian Baroque]] [[Category:Earthquakes in Malta]] [[Category:1693 tsunamis]] [[Category:1693 in the Kingdom of Sicily]]

revision.comment: /* The History of Improving the A354 Dorchester Road */ Fix misspelling found by [[Wikipedia:Typo Team/moss]] – you can help!
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Redirect|A354|the ASTM standard|ASTM A354}} {{Infobox road |country=GBR |type=A |route=354 |image=| |image_notes= Weymouth Relief Road |length_mi=51 |direction_a= North |terminus_a = [[Salisbury]]
{{coord|51.0571|-1.7946|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A354 road (northeastern end)}} |direction_b= South |terminus_b = [[Isle of Portland|Portland]]
{{coord|50.5629|-2.4493|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline|name=A354 road (southwestern end)}} |junction = {{ukroadsmall|338}}
{{ukroadsmall|350}}
{{ukroadsmall-svg|35}}
{{ukroadsmall|352}}
{{ukroadsmall|353}} |destinations= [[Salisbury]], [[Blandford Forum]], [[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]], [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]] }} The '''A354''' is a [[primary route]] in [[England]] which runs from [[Salisbury]] in [[Wiltshire]] to [[Villages of Portland|Easton]] on the [[Isle of Portland]] in [[Dorset]], a total distance of {{convert|51|mi}}. From Salisbury the road crosses [[Cranborne Chase]] and briefly merges with the [[A350 road|A350]] at the [[Blandford Forum]] bypass before crossing the [[Dorset Downs]] and merging with the [[A35 road|A35]] at the [[Puddletown]] bypass. {{convert|7|mi}} to the west it splits from the [[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]] bypass and runs south. The road now bypasses [[Upwey, Dorset|Upwey]] and [[Broadwey]] on a new section of road which has some 2 lane sections going north and 1 lane continuously going south towards [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]]. After the old and new sections meet at Manor Roundabout the road follows down Weymouth Way alongside [[Radipole Lake]]. The final stretch runs across a short bridge over [[Chesil Beach#The Fleet Lagoon|Chesil beach]] onto Portland. ==Weymouth Relief Road== The project was to build a {{convert|3.75|mi|km|adj=on}} single carriageway road, with crawler lane along part, linking the A354 Manor Roundabout near Radipole to the A354 at the top of the Ridgeway Hill. The main carriageway of the Weymouth Relief Road opened on Thursday 17 March 2011. The 2012 Olympics at Portland played a major factor in making £89m funding for the road available. ==The History of Improving the A354 Dorchester Road== 1983 - The Dorset Structure Plan proposed to construct the A354 Weymouth, Ridgeway to Mount Pleasant improvement as a primary route. December 1987 to April 1988 - a public inquiry was held into proposals for development in the Lorton area which included a new single-carriageway route running from Mount Pleasant to Littlemoor. These proposals were refused consent by the Secretary of State. Between 1989 and 1992 - various studies and consultation exercises undertaken into alternative route options and alignments for a dual carriageway road between the Ridgeway and north Weymouth. 1992 - work on a planning application and Environmental Statement for this scheme began. July 1994 - a dual carriageway road along the alignment was granted planning permission. 1996 - A public inquiry into the Compulsory Purchase and Side Road Orders was held. The Secretary of State approved these orders. However, work on the scheme was never started as, following a Government review of road construction, the funding for the scheme was not forthcoming. The planning permission lapsed after 5 years. Following the lapse of permission Dorset County Council undertook a review of the previously consented scheme. The previous dual carriageway route was rejected in light of changing policy guidance, developments within the area of the proposed route and new information about the ecological value of areas along the route. A new preferred route for a single carriageway road was identified, running from Manor Roundabout alongside the eastern side of the Weymouth/Dorchester railway to Littlemoor, through Littlemoor and then parallel with the alignment of the railway to the Ridgeway (often referred to as the Orange Route). December 2003 - the Government Office of the South West confirmed that this scheme was 'Provisionally Accepted', subject to completion of all relevant statutory processes and final approval of Ministers. September 2005 - a planning application and Environmental Statement for a road along the preferred route was submitted by Dorset County Council. However, the application was not determined as, following its submission and at the request of the planning authority, the council carried out further studies, including an examination of the potential for further reducing the effects on the environment, especially those parts which are nationally designated. As a result of the council's re-assessment, changes were made to the September 2005 proposals, primarily to the stretch of road through the AONB. March 2011 - Relief Road was opened ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{GeoGroupTemplate}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110701045628/http://www.dorsetforyou.com/weymouthreliefroad Dorset for you - Weymouth Relief Road] {{GB A road zone 3}} {{coord|50.8472|-2.1663|dim:50000_region:GB|display=title|name=A354 road}} {{DEFAULTSORT:3-0354}} [[Category:Roads in England]] [[Category:Roads in Dorset]] [[Category:Roads in Wiltshire]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | image = Albert_Paddock_Crary_in_1959.jpg | caption = Albert Paddock Crary in 1959 | birth_name = Albert Paddock Crary | birth_date = {{Birth date|1911|7|25}} | birth_place = [[Pierrepont, New York]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1987|10|29|1911|7|25}} | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], United States | resting_place = Pierrepont Hill Cemetery, Pierrepont, New York | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[Geophysics]], [[Glaciology]] | education = [[St. Lawrence University]]
[[Lehigh University]] | known_for = [[Polar exploration]] | prizes = [[Cullum Geographical Medal]] (1959)
[[Gold Medal (RGS)|Patron's Gold Medal]] (1963)
[[Swedish Society for Anthropology and Geography|Vega Medal]] (1972) | spouse = Mildred R. Rodgers | parents = Frank J. Crary and Ella Paddock Crary | children = Frank J. Crary III | relatives = [[Oringe Smith Crary]] (great-great-great-uncle)
[[Scott Crary]] (cousin) | office = Chief Scientist for the United States Antarctic Research Program| term_start =1960 | term_end =1968 | appointed = | predecessor = | successor = }} '''Albert Paddock Crary''' (July 25, 1911 – October 29, 1987), was a pioneer polar [[geophysics|geophysicist]] and [[glaciology|glaciologist]]. He was the first person to have stepped foot on both the North and South Poles, having made it to the [[North Pole]] on May 3, 1952 (with [[Joseph O. Fletcher]] and [[William P. Benedict]]) and then to the [[South Pole]] on February 12, 1961, as the leader of a team of eight.{{cite web | url=http://journals.cambridge.org/download.php?file=%2FPOL%2FPOL24_149%2FS0032247400009049a.pdf&code=b61bfadf972f924db1a15cd526574854 | author = de Q. Robin, Gordon |title=Obituary | date= November 1987 | publisher= Cambridge Journals }} The South Pole expedition set out from [[McMurdo Station]] on December 10, 1960, using three [[Snowcat]]s with trailers. Crary was the seventh expedition leader to arrive at the South Pole by surface transportation (the six others before him were—in sequence—[[Roald Amundsen|Amundsen]], [[Robert Falcon Scott|Scott]], [[Edmund Hillary|Hillary]], [[Vivian Fuchs|Fuchs]], a Russian expedition in 1959/60 from [[Vostok, Antarctica|Vostok base]], and Antero Havola).{{cite web |url=http://www.polartrec.com/expeditions/human-impacts-in-antarctica-2011/journals/2011-11-28 | author = Brown, Michelle |title=Welcome to Crary | date= 28 November 2011 | publisher= PolarTREC Journal }} He was widely admired for his intellect, wit, skills and as a great administrator for polar research expeditions.{{cite web |url=http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic41-1-89.pdf | author = Staff |title=Albert Paddock Crary | date= January 1989 | publisher= Arctic Institute of North America – University of Calgary }} ==Biography== Crary was born in 1911 into a farming family in northern New York State. He was the second oldest in a family of 7 children. He was a physics major and geology student at [[St. Lawrence University]] in [[Canton, New York]]. He graduated in 1931 [[Phi Beta Kappa]] from [[St. Lawrence University]] and then enrolled at [[Lehigh University]] to obtain a master's degree in physics. After spending years completing and facilitating research at both poles, Crary eventually settled in [[Bethesda, Maryland]], with his wife and son. His awards included the [[Cullum Geographical Medal]] (1959), the [[Gold Medal (RGS)|Patron's Gold Medal]] (1963), and the [[Swedish Society for Anthropology and Geography|Vega Medal]] (1972). He died on October 29, 1987, at the [[George Washington University Hospital]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/obituaries/albert-crary-geophysicist-dies-an-explorer-of-both-polar-regions.html | author = [[Edward Hudson (reporter)|Hudson, Edward]] |title=Albert Crary, Geophysicist, Dies. An Explorer of Both Polar Regions | date= 31 October 1987 | publisher= [[The New York Times]] }} ==Legacy== In 1991, the [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF), which manages the [[U.S. Antarctic Program]] (USAP), honoured his memory by dedicating a state-of-the-art laboratory complex in his name, the [[Albert P. Crary Science and Engineering Center]] (CSEC) located in [[McMurdo Station]]. He was also honored by having the [[Crary Mountains]] (76 degrees 48' S, 117 degrees 40' W) and the [[Crary Ice Rise]] in Antarctica named for him as well.{{cite web |url=http://www.igsoc.org:8080/journal/34/116/igs_journal_vol34_issue116_pg139-140.pdf |author=Bentley, Charles |title=Albert P. Crary |date=1988 |publisher=Journal of Glaciology |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924033323/http://www.igsoc.org:8080/journal/34/116/igs_journal_vol34_issue116_pg139-140.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }} ==Contributions== Dr. Crary contributed in a variety of important ways to his field including: [[File:Dr._Albert_Paddock_Crary_with_team_at_the_North_Pole.jpg|right|thumb|185px|Crary and his team at the North Pole in 1952]] * Chief Scientist for Arctic ice island T3, 1952–1955 * Established the United States Geological Headquarters for the [[International Geophysical Year]], 1955 * Deputy Leader of United States science during the International Geophysical Year, 1957 * Leader of the U.S. seismic traverse of Ross Ice Shelf, 1957–58 * Leader, geophysical traverse W from Little America V, up Skelton Glacier to the Victoria Land plateau and W along the 78 parallel to c. 13130E, 1958–59 * Leader, geophysical traverse from McMurdo Station via Skelton Glacier to the South Pole, 1960–61 * Chief Scientist, United States Antarctic Research Program, 1960–1968 * Deputy then Director, Division of Environmental Sciences, National Science Foundation, 1969–1978 * Member of ACAN, 1961-76 (Chairman, 1974–76) He worked with many notable scientists and famous institutions: * Dr. [[Maurice Ewing]] of [[Columbia University]] and [[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution]] * Assisted Dr. James Peoples at MOGUL ([[Project Mogul]]) as the Field Operations Director using meteorological balloons to experiment with different types of equipment to collect and transmit sound waves in the upper atmosphere ([[Roswell incident]]- see [http://muller.lbl.gov/teaching/physics10/Roswell/USMogulReport.html]) ==See also== *[[List of polar explorers]] == External links == *[http://www.southpolestation.com/trivia/igy1/igy1.html#crary Crary's trip to the South Pole] with an image and a map. *[http://www.nationalacademies.org/history/igy/images/se116.gif Picture of Crary] when he was Deputy Chief Scientist of the NAS's US-IGY Antarctic program, shown reading a seismograph record. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Polar exploration|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crary, Albert P.}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:Lehigh University alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cullum Geographical Medal]] [[Category:American geophysicists]] [[Category:Glaciologists]] [[Category:St. Lawrence University alumni]]

revision.text:
{{About|the human geography and sociological term|the geomorphological meaning|Drainage basin}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2008}}
In [[human geography]], a '''catchment area''' is the area from which a city, service or institution attracts a population that uses its services. For example, a school catchment area is the [[geographic]] area from which students are eligible to attend a local [[school]].
Governments and [[community service]] organizations often define catchment areas for planning purposes and [[public safety]] such as ensuring universal access to services like fire departments, police departments, ambulance bases and hospitals.
==Creation== Catchment areas are generally established and modified by local governments. These boundaries can be modeled using [[geographic information system]]s (GIS).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McLafferty |first1=Sara L. |title=GIS and Health Care |journal=Annual Review of Public Health |volume=24 |issue= |pages=25–42 |year=2003 |pmid=12668754 |doi=10.1146/annurev.publhealth.24.012902.141012 }}</ref> There can be large variability in the services provided within different catchments in the same area depending upon how and when those catchments were established.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jenkins |first1=C. |last2=Campbell |first2=J. |title=Catchment areas in general practice and their relation to size and quality of practice and deprivation: a descriptive study in one London borough |journal=BMJ |volume=313 |issue=7066 |pages=1189–92 |year=1996 |pmid=8916754 |pmc=2352502 |doi=10.1136/bmj.313.7066.1189 }}</ref> They are usually contiguous but can overlap when they describe competing services.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Schuurman |first1=Nadine |last2=Fiedler |first2=Robert S |last3=Grzybowski |first3=Stefan CW |last4=Grund |first4=Darrin |title=Defining rational hospital catchments for non-urban areas based on travel-time |journal=International Journal of Health Geographics |volume=5 |issue= |pages=43 |year=2006 |pmid=17018146 |pmc=1617091 |doi=10.1186/1476-072X-5-43 }}</ref>
===Defining=== Catchments can be defined based upon a number of factors including distance to the facility, actual travel time to the facility, geographic boundaries or population within the catchment. In a distance based catchment, the area serviced will often depend on the number of visits expected to that institution by each individual. For example, it may be more acceptable to have a larger catchment for a hospital where any one individual will have few annual visits in comparison to a school where visits will be daily and hence desired distance would be closer. When a facility’s capacity can only service a certain volume, the catchment may be used to limit a population’s ability to access services outside that area.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Parsons |first1=Eddie |last2=Chalkley |first2=Brian |last3=Jones |first3=Allan |title=School Catchments and Pupil Movements: A case study in parental choice |journal=Educational Studies |volume=26 |issue=1 |year=2000 |pages=33–48 |doi=10.1080/03055690097727 }}</ref> For example, children may be unable to enroll in a school outside their catchment to prevent the school's services being exceeded.
==Examples== *[[Airport]]s can be built and maintained in locations which minimize the driving distance for the surrounding population to reach them.<ref>{{cite web |title=Airports: Non-Financial Analysis |publisher=[[Transport Canada]] |url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/programs/airports/RSAS/nonfinanalysis.htm }}</ref> *A neighborhood or district of a city often has several small convenience shops, each with a catchment area of several streets. Supermarkets, on the other hand, have a much lower density, with catchment areas of several neighborhoods (or several villages in rural areas). This principle, similar to the [[central place theory]], makes catchment areas an important area of study for [[geographers]], [[economists]], and [[urban planners]]. *In Nigeria, most Federal Schools respect the fact that some states are educationally less developed than others. The country's higher education <ref>{{cite web |title=Admission: University Admission |publisher=Students Nigeria |url=https://www.students.com.ng/category/admission }}</ref> catchment areas have therefore been designed to ensure a good mixture of students from different backgrounds.
==See also== *[[Hinterland]] *[[School district]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{fr}} [http://www.owlapps.net/application-geomarketing/ http://www.owlapps.net/application-geomarketing: catchment area calculations free webapp ] * [https://www.students.com.ng/list-nigerian-universities-catchment-areas: List of Nigerian Universities Catchment Areas ]
[[Category:Human geography]] [[Category:Economic geography]]

[[File:Europe 1815 map en.png|thumb|550px|A map of Europe after the [[Congress of Vienna]], 1815.]] This article gives a detailed listing of all the countries, including [[puppet state]]s, that have existed in [[Europe]] since the [[Congress of Vienna]] in 1815 to the present day. Each country has information separated into columns: name of the distinct country, its lifespan, the country or countries that hold all or some of the territory it once did, and further information about it.This information is based on the main articles on these former countries.{{cite web |url=http://www.progenealogists.com/germany/articles/ganatomy.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101081203/http://www.progenealogists.com/germany/articles/ganatomy.htm |archivedate=2009-11-01 |df= }} == Article scope == {{Further|Congress of Vienna|Concert of Europe}} The scope of this article begins in 1815, after a round of negotiations about European borders and spheres of influence were agreed upon at the [[Congress of Vienna]].{{cite web|last=Bloy|first=Marjie|title=The Congress of Vienna, 1 November 1814 – 8 June 1815|publisher=The Victorian Web|date=30 April 2002|url=http://www.victorianweb.org/history/forpol/vienna.html|accessdate=2009-01-09}} The Congress of Vienna was a nine-month, pan-European meeting of statesmen who met to settle the many issues arising from the destabilising impact of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]], the [[Napoleonic Wars]], and the dissolution of the [[Holy Roman Empire]].{{cite web|last=Bloy|first=Marjie|title=The Congress of Vienna, 1 November 1814 – 8 June 1815|publisher=The Victorian Web|date=30 April 2002|url=http://www.victorianweb.org/history/forpol/vienna.html|accessdate=2009-01-09}} The immediate background was [[First French Empire|Napoleonic France's]] defeat and [[Treaty of Paris (1814)|surrender in May 1814]], which brought an end to twenty-five years of nearly continuous war during which France had caused the [[annexation]] or geopolitical reorganisation of myriad European microstates as well as some larger ones. The Congress of Vienna was the first of a series of international meetings that came to be known as the [[Concert of Europe]], which was an attempt to forge a peaceful [[balance of power in international relations|balance of power]] in Europe,{{cite web|last=Bloy|first=Marjie|title=The Congress of Vienna, 1 November 1814 – 8 June 1815|publisher=The Victorian Web|date=30 April 2002|url=http://www.victorianweb.org/history/forpol/vienna.html|accessdate=2009-01-09}} including restoring or reorganising many of the states which had previously been removed from Europe's political map. ==Sovereign countries== This is a list of all the independent countries or [[puppet state]]s that existed between 1815 and the present day that no longer exist. (Lifespan of each is based on that country's sovereignty. This means that those countries may have existed outside of those dates as well but not under full independence.) {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Former countries ! Lifespan of sovereignty ! Today part of ! Notes |- | [[Duchy of Anhalt|Anhalt (Duchy)]] | 1813–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]]. |- | [[First Republic of Armenia|Armenia (Democratic Republic)]] | 1918–1920 | [[Armenia]] | The [[Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic]] temporarily broke up and the Democratic Republic of Armenia was created as one of its successor states but was reunified with the other two to create the [[Transcaucasian SSR]] in 1922. |- | [[Austrian Empire]] | 1804–1867 | [[Austria]], [[Hungary]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Slovakia]], [[Galicia (eastern Europe)|Poland, Ukraine]], [[Transylvania|Romania]], [[Vojvodina|Serbia]], [[Italy]], [[Slovenia]], [[Croatia]] | The first unified empire under the [[Habsburg Monarchy]] until Hungarian uprisings in 1848 and the [[Hungarian Compromise]] of 1867. |- | [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]] | 1867–1918 | [[Austria]], [[Hungary]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Slovakia]], [[Galicia (eastern Europe)|Poland, Ukraine]], [[Transylvania|Romania]], [[Vojvodina|Serbia]], [[Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol|Italy]], [[Slovenia]], [[Croatia]], [[Bosnia & Herzegovina]] | Successor state of the [[Austrian Empire]] with Hungarian self-government within the Habsburg Empire. |- | [[Avar Khanate]] | 13th century–1864 | [[Russia]] | Comprised [[Circassia]] and [[Dagestan]]; it was the last country in the Caucasus to be annexed by the [[Russian Empire]]: Dagestan in 1859 and Circassia in 1864. |- | [[Azerbaijan Democratic Republic|Azerbaijan (Democratic Republic)]] | 1918–1920 | [[Azerbaijan]] | The [[Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic]] temporarily broke up and the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic was created as one of its successor states but was reunified with the other two to create the [[Transcaucasian SSR]] in 1922. |- | [[Grand Duchy of Baden|Baden (Grand Duchy)]] | 1806–1871 | [[Germany]] | Joined the [[German Empire]] and became one of its members. |- | [[Kingdom of Bavaria|Bavaria (Kingdom)]] | 1806–1871 | [[Germany]] | Joined the [[German Empire]] and became one of its members. |- | [[Belarusian People's Republic|Belarus (People's Republic)]] | 1918–1919 | [[Belarus]] | Gained independence from the Russian SFSR and quickly was swallowed by the Russian Soviets. Currently, its Rada (Council) is the oldest [[government in exile]] still functioning. |- | [[Bremen (state)|Bremen (Free City)]] | 1813–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Duchy of Brunswick|Brunswick (Duchy)]] | 1815–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Carpatho-Ukraine]] | 1938–1939 | [[Ukraine]] | It was an autonomous region within [[Czechoslovakia]] from late 1938 to March 15, 1939. It declared itself an independent republic on March 15, 1939, but was annexed by [[Kingdom of Hungary (Regency)|Hungary]] between March 15 and March 16, 1939, remaining under Hungarian control until the end of [[World War II]], when it was ceded to the [[Soviet Union]]. |- | [[Republic of Cospaia|Cospaia]] | 1440–1826 | [[Italy]] | By error, a small strip of land went unmentioned in a sale treaty, and its inhabitants promptly declared independence; nearly 400 years later it was absorbed into the Papal States and Tuscany equally. |- | [[Couto Misto]] | 10th century–1864 | [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]] | Neutral territory between [[Portugal]] and [[Spain]] which was divided between Portugal and Spain in 1864. |- | [[Cretan State]] | 1898–1913 | [[Greece]] | Gained independence after several rebellions against the [[Ottoman Empire]] and after only 15 years of independence joined the [[Kingdom of Greece]]. |- | [[Republic of Crimea (country)|Crimea (Republic)]] | 2014 | [[Ukraine]] (disputed with [[Russia]]) | Unrecognized state which gained independence after a [[Crimean referendum, 2014|referendum]] and then joined Russia a day later. |- | [[Independent State of Croatia|Croatia (puppet state of Nazi Germany)]] | 1941–1945 | [[Croatia]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Serbia]] | A [[puppet state]] of [[Nazi Germany]] during World War II. |- | [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovakia (Democratic Republic)]] | [[First Czechoslovak Republic|1918–1938]]
[[Second Czechoslovak Republic|1938–1939]]
[[History of Czechoslovakia (1945–48)|1945–1948]] | [[Czech Republic]], [[Slovakia]], [[Zakarpattia Oblast|Ukraine]] | Democratic unified government of the Czechs and Slovaks after World War I . |- | [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovakia (People's Republic)]] | 1948–1992 | [[Czech Republic]], [[Slovakia]] | Communist government of the Czechs and Slovaks after World War II behind the [[Iron Curtain]]. |- | [[Free City of Danzig|Danzig (League of Nations)]] | 1920–1939 | [[Poland]] | Protectorate of the [[League of Nations]]; annexed by [[Nazi Germany]] during the invasion of [[Second Polish Republic|Poland]] in World War II. |- | [[Gurian Republic]] | 1905-06 | [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | Part of the Russian Empire. |- | [[German Democratic Republic]] | 1949–1990 | [[Germany]] | Also known as East Germany; was the Soviet-controlled government of Germany after World War II. |- | [[Finnish Democratic Republic]] | 1939–1940 | [[Russia]] | A [[puppet state]] of the [[Soviet Union]] during World War II created from southern Finland which was quickly annexed into the [[Soviet Union]] |- | [[Free City of Frankfurt|Frankfurt (Free City)]] | 1816–1866 | [[Germany]] | Annexed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] in 1866 |- | [[Democratic Republic of Georgia|Georgia (Democratic Republic)]] | 1918–1921 | [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | The [[Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic]] temporarily broke up and the Democratic Republic of Georgia was created as one of its successor states but was reunified with the other two to create the [[Transcaucasian SSR]] in 1922 |- | [[Kingdom of Greece|Greece (Kingdom)]] | 1832–1924
1935–1941
1944–1974 | [[Greece]], [[Turkey]] | Wavering between monarchy and dictatorship the Kingdom of Greece existed three times in history always on rocky foundations |- | [[Hamburg|Hamburg (Free City)]] | 1813–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Kingdom of Hanover|Hanover (Kingdom)]] | 1814–1866 | [[Germany]] | In personal union with the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] until accession of [[Queen Victoria]] in 1837; annexed by the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] in 1866. |- | [[Grand Duchy of Hesse|Hesse (Grand Duchy)]] | 1806–1867/1871 | [[Germany]] | Northern part became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] and then the [[German Empire]], with the southern part joining the [[German Empire]] as well. |- | [[Hesse-Homburg]] | 1622–1866 | [[Germany]] | Annexed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] in 1866 |- | [[Electorate of Hesse|Hesse-Kassel]] | 1813–1866 | [[Germany]] | Annexed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] in 1866 |- | [[Hohenzollern-Hechingen]] | 1576–1850 | [[Germany]] | Annexed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] in 1850 |- | [[Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen]] | 1576–1850 | [[Germany]] | Annexed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] in 1850 |- | [[Italian Social Republic]] | 1943–1945 | [[Italy]] | A [[puppet state]] of Nazi Germany during World War II |- | [[Irish Republic]] | 1919–1922 | [[Northern Ireland|United Kingdom]], [[Ireland]] | Partly recognized, revolutionary state. Declared independence from the United Kingdom after the [[Irish general election, 1918|1918 election]] during the [[Irish War of Independence]]. Partitioned into the [[Irish Free State]] and [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]] after the 1921 [[Anglo-Irish Treaty]]. |- | [[Free City of Kraków|Kraków (Free City)]] | 1815–1846 | [[Poland]] | Protectorate of the Kingdom of Prussia, the Russian Empire and the Empire of Austria, later annexed into the Austrian Empire |- | [[Kuban People's Republic]] | 1917–1920 | [[Russia]] | From the fall of the [[Russian Empire]] in 1917 until it was annexed by the [[Russian SFSR]] it existed as a small short-lived country in the Northern Caucasus and has never regained its independence |- | [[Principality of Lichtenberg|Lichtenberg (Principality)]] | 1815–1834 | [[Germany]] | Owned by a branch of the Saxe-Coburgs; sold to the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] in 1834 |- | [[Principality of Lippe|Lippe (Principality)]] | 1123–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Free City of Lübeck|Lübeck (Free City)]] | 1815–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Duchy of Lucca|Lucca (Duchy)]] | 1815–1847 | [[Italy]] | Annexed by [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany|Tuscany]] in 1847 |- | [[Duchy of Massa and Carrara|Massa and Carrara (Duchy)]] | 1473–1829 | [[Italy]] | Annexed by [[Duchy of Modena and Reggio|Modena and Reggio]] in 1829 |- | [[Grand Duchy of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] | 1352–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Menton|Free Cities of Menton and Roquebrune]] | 1848-1849 | [[France]] | The Free Cities of [[Menton]] and [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin|Roquebrune]] seceded from [[Monaco]] in 1848. In November 1849 they were annexed by [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Sardinia]], and in 1861 were annexed by France. |- | [[Duchy of Modena and Reggio|Modena and Reggio (Duchy)]] | 1814–1859 | [[Italy]] | Joined the [[United Provinces of Central Italy]], (one of the predecessors of the [[Kingdom of Italy]]) |- | [[Moldavian Democratic Republic]] | 1918 | [[Moldova]] | From the fall of the [[Russian Empire]] in 1917 until 1918 and the Versailles Treaty which added this territory to the [[Kingdom of Romania]] the Moldavian Democratic Republic existed as one of the Imperial Russian successor countries in Europe |- | [[Kingdom of Montenegro|Montenegro (Kingdom)]] | 1910–1918 | [[Montenegro]] | A kingdom which was annexed by Serbia during the Serbian Expansion after World War I to create Yugoslavia |- | [[Principality of Montenegro|Montenegro (Principality)]] | 1878–1910 | [[Montenegro]] | Predecessor of the [[Kingdom of Montenegro]] |- | [[Mountainous Republic of the Northern Caucasus]] | 1917–1920 | [[Russia]] | From the fall of the [[Russian Empire]] in 1917 until 1920 this country existed for a short time before annexation by the [[Russian SFSR]] and never has regained independence |- | [[Duchy of Nassau|Nassau (Duchy)]] | 1806–1866 | [[Germany]] | Annexed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] in 1866 |- | [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] | 1867–1871 | [[Germany]], [[Poland]], [[Northern Schleswig|Denmark]], [[Kaliningrad Oblast|Russia]] | First federal German state and predecessor of the [[German Empire]] |- | [[Grand Duchy of Oldenburg|Oldenburg (Grand Duchy)]] | 1180–1867 | [[Germany]] | Became a member of the [[North German Confederation|North German Confederation Federal State]] |- | [[Ottoman Empire]] | 1299–1923 | [[Turkey]], [[Bosnia & Herzegovina]], [[Serbia]], [[Romania]], [[Montenegro]], [[Albania]], [[Macedonia (country)|Macedonia]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]], [[Hungary]], [[Moldova]], [[Ukraine]], [[Iraq]], [[Syria]], [[Kuwait]], [[Lebanon]], [[Israel]], [[Palestinian territories|Palestine]], [[Egypt]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Libya]], [[Tunisia]], [[Algeria]] | One of the longest lasting empires of all time this empire rose out of the Near East and fluctuated drastically in territory and economic status throughout its history; it was dissolved after its defeat in World War 1. |- | [[Papal States]] | 752–1870 | [[Italy]] | The entire eastern region joined the [[United Provinces of Central Italy]], (one of the predecessors of the [[Kingdom of Italy]]); however, the remaining strip of land along the west coast did not join Italy until it was annexed in 1870 |- | [[Duchy of Parma|Parma (Duchy)]] | 1814–1859 | [[Italy]] | joined the [[United Provinces of Central Italy]], (one of the A '''geometric network''' is an object commonly used in [[geographic information systems]] to model a series of interconnected features. A geometric network is similar to a [[Graph (discrete mathematics)|graph]] in [[mathematics]] and [[computer science]], and can be described and analyzed using theories and concepts similar to [[graph theory]]. Geometric networks are often used to model road networks and public utility networks (such as electric, gas, and water utilities).<ref>{{cite book|last=Meehan|first=Bill|title=Empowering Electric and Gas Utilities with GIS|year=2007|publisher=ESRI}}</ref>
==Composition of a Geometric Network==
A geometric network is composed of '''edges''' that are connected. Connectivity rules for the network specify which edges are connected and at what points they are connected, commonly referred to as '''junction''' or '''intersection''' points. These edges can have weights or flow direction assigned to them, which dictate certain properties of these edges that affect analysis results<ref>{{cite web|last=Childs|first=Colin|title=ArcGIS Network Analyst: Networks and Network Models|url=http://www.esri.com/news/podcasts/transcripts/arcgisnetworkanalyst_networksandnetworkmodels.pdf|publisher=ESRI Inc.|accessdate=22 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403011630/http://www.esri.com/news/podcasts/transcripts/arcgisnetworkanalyst_networksandnetworkmodels.pdf|archivedate=3 April 2012|df=}}</ref> . In the case of certain types of networks, source points (points where flow originates) and sink points (points where flow terminates) may also exist. In the case of utility networks, a source point may correlate with an electric substation or a water pumping station, and a sink point may correlate with a service connection at a residential household.<ref>{{cite book|last=Meehan|first=Bill|title=Empowering Electric and Gas Utilities with GIS|year=2007|publisher=ESRI}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Evans|first=James Robert|title=Algorithms for Networks and Graphs, Volume 1|year=1992|publisher=Marcel Dekker, Inc.}}</ref>
==Functions==
Networks define the interconnectedness of features. Through analyzing this connectivity, paths from one point to another on the network can be traced and calculated. Through optimization algorithms and utilizing network weights and flow, these paths can also be optimized to show specialized paths, such as the shortest path between two points on the network, as is commonly done in the calculation of driving directions. Networks can also be used to perform spatial analysis to determine points or edges that are encompassed in a certain area or within a certain distance of a specified point. This has applications in [[hydrology]] and [[urban planning]], among other fields.
==Applications==
* [[Routing]]: for calculating driving directions, paths from one point of interest to another, locating nearby points of interest * [[Urban Planning]]: for site suitability studies, and traffic and congestion studies. * [[Electric Utility]] Industry: for modeling an [[electrical grid]] in GIS, tracing from a generation source * [[Public Utility|Other Public Utilities]]: for modeling water distribution flow and natural gas distribution
==See also== * [[Graph (discrete mathematics)|Graphs]] * [[Graph theory]] * [[Geographic Information Systems]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geographic information systems]]

revision.text:
'''Hierocles''' ([[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: Ἱεροκλῆς ''Hierokles'') was a [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] geographer of the sixth century and the attributed author of the ''[[Synecdemus]]'' or ''Synekdemos'', which contains a table of administrative divisions of the Byzantine Empire and lists of the cities of each. The work is dated to the reign of [[Justinian]] but prior to 535, as it divides the 912 listed cities in the Empire among 64 [[Eparchy|Eparchies]]. The ''Synecdemus'' is thus one of the most invaluable monuments which we have to study the political geography of the sixth century East. The work of Hierocles along with that of [[Stephanus of Byzantium]] were the principal sources of [[Constantine VII]]'s work on the [[Theme (Byzantine district)|Theme]]s (''De Thematibus''). Hierocles was published by Parthey (Hieroclis Synecdemus; Berlin, 1866) then in a corrected text, by A. Burckhardt in the [[Teubner]] series ([https://books.google.com/books?id=HIITK93F54wC Hieroclis Synecdemus; Leipzig, 1893]). The most recent major publication was by E. Honigmann (''Le Synekdèmos d'Hiéroklès et l'opuscule géographique de Georges de Chypre''; Brussels, 1939).
The Synecdemus of Hierocles should not be confused with a [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek Orthodox]] prayer book by the same name.
==References== * Getzel Cohen, The Hellenistic Settlements in Europe, the Islands, and Asia Minor ({{ISBN|0-520-08329-6}}), p. 7. * Wolfgang Buchwald, Dictionnaire des auteurs grecs et latins de l'Antiquité et du Moyen-Âge, s. v. Hiéroclès, p. 408. * [[Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium]], s. v. Hierokles, vol. II, 930.
==External links== * [http://soltdm.com/sources/mss/hierocl/hierocles.htm Synecdemus (the Balkanic provinces), with 2 maps] at SOLTDM.COM
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hierocles}} [[Category:Byzantine geographers]] [[Category:6th-century Byzantine people]] [[Category:6th-century Byzantine writers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]]

{{advert|date=August 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=December 2009}}{{No footnotes|date=February 2018}}{{Infobox organization | image = ICMM logo.jpg | formation = 2001 | type = Industry peak body | headquarters = London, UK | services = Mining and Minerals peak body | key_people = | name = International Council on Mining and Metals (ICMM) | membership = African Rainbow Minerals
